title: Rare Baulkham Hills bungalow has a hidden 1939 penny with a special link to WWII
text:
Underneath the clothesline in the backyard of this Baulkham Hills home is a 1939 penny set in a concrete base.

The coin is believed to have been placed there by the original owners when one of their sons headed off to fight on the front lines of WWII.

Iconic ‘Gone With the Wind’ House sells

This piece of history gives a poignant insight into what life was like in suburban Sydney 80 years ago during war time.

The classic Californian bungalow — set on a 954 sqm block in a cul-de-sac location at 19 Woodlands Street — has been beautifully restored with many features reminiscent of yesteryear.

It is one of the few remaining homes of its style in suburb.

Vendor Jen Childs, a property stylist, is the fourth owner of the property and has always been fascinated with its history.

An elderly neighbour was able to share some of the home’s past such as the significance of the penny under the Hills hoist. It is believed the home had been owned by the Telfer family.

“Our house was the only one that had a phone — so anyone who needed the doctor or whatever would come here to make a call,” Ms Childs said.

“We know one of the owner’s sons went off to war and I think the mother put the penny in the concrete as a lucky symbol that he would come home.

“We don’t know much about the soldier although I did try to look him up online but with no luck so I haven’t been able to verify the story.”

The home has a north-facing parklike rear garden with mature trees and sprawling lawn.

It is an idyllic outdoor space for families that is hard to find in newer housing estates of today.

The residence also has charming street appeal with its box bay window, veranda and terracotta tiled roof.

Stepping inside its renovated interior, it is clear that the bungalow’s character has not been lost even with its contemporary updates.

Dramatic dark walls contrast with bright white ceilings and skirting boards. It has high ceilings, decorative cornices, picture rails, polished floorboards and slash style windows.

Inside Sam Armytage's country retreat Inside Sam Armytage's country retreat

The kitchen, with stone benchtops and Bosch gas appliances, adjoins the open planned family and meals area. A wall of sliding French timber doors opens up to reveal a large deck overlooking the garden.

A separate lounge room, with a jetmaster wood-burning fireplace, is the perfect winter retreat and offers a second living space. The updated bathroom is also in keeping with the home’s 1939 vintage.

After 17 years of ownership, the family have decided it is time to move one but admit it will be hard to leave.

“I think our favourite spot has been the backyard and also the open flow to the house,” Ms Childs said.

“We have the backdoors wide open and we can see the beautiful tree out the back — it feels like you are in the outdoors even when you are sitting inside. It really does look like a park and that is what I will miss the most.”

The property is being auctioned on Saturday November 9 at 10.45am though Jennifer Carr from Louis Carr Real Estate.
